qas.question: Who introduced the phalanx formation into Rome's army?
Were Roman soldiers expected to purchase their own equipment?

answers.text: wealthiest citizens, who were able to purchase the best equipment

qas.question: Who were contained in the first rank of the phalanx formation?
From what people did it appear the Etruscans had model their form of warfare on?

context: During this period, Roman soldiers seem to have been modelled after those of the Etruscans to the north, who themselves seem to have copied their style of warfare from the <a3_0>Greeks<a3_0/>. Traditionally, the introduction of the phalanx formation into the Roman army is ascribed to the city's penultimate king, <a0_0>Servius Tullius<a0_0/> (ruled 578 to 534 BC). According to Livy and Dionysius of <a4_0>Halicarnassus<a4_0/>, the front rank was composed of the <a1_0><a2_0>wealthiest citizens<a2_0/>, who were able to purchase the best equipment<a1_0/>. Each subsequent rank consisted of those with less wealth and poorer equipment than the one before it.
